sn47.21:1.2: At one time the venerables Ānanda and Bhadda were staying near Pāṭaliputta, in the Chicken Monastery.
sn47.21:1.3: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Bhadda came out of retreat, went to Venerable Ānanda, and exchanged greetings with him.
sn47.21:1.4: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to Ānanda:
sn47.21:1.5: “Reverend Ānanda, the Buddha has spoken of skillful ethics. What’s their purpose?”
sn47.21:2.2: Your approach and articulation are excellent, and it’s a good question.
sn47.21:2.4: ‘The Buddha has spoken of skillful ethics. What’s their purpose?’”
sn47.21:2.6: “The Buddha has spoken of skillful ethics to the extent necessary for developing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
sn47.21:3.2: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.21:3.3: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …
sn47.21:3.5: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.21:3.6: The Buddha has spoken of skillful ethics to the extent necessary for developing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.”
